author: Reuters
title: Le bÃ©nÃ©fice de Weyerhaeuser s'effondre en raison de la faiblesse des ventes et de la tiÃ©deur de la demande - 24/10/2024 Ã  23:29 - Boursorama
text:
((Traduction automatisÃ©e par Reuters, veuillez consulter la clause de non-responsabilitÃ© https://bit.ly/rtrsauto))
La sociÃ©tÃ© amÃ©ricaine de produits forestiers Weyerhaeuser WY.N a annoncÃ© jeudi une chute de 88% de son bÃ©nÃ©fice au troisiÃ¨me trimestre en raison d'une faible demande pour ses produits dans un contexte de faiblesse du marchÃ© de l'immobilier. Les ventes de logements existants aux Ã‰tats-Unis ont baissÃ© en septembre () pour atteindre leur niveau le plus bas depuis 14 ans, en raison des taux hypothÃ©caires Ã©levÃ©s et des prix de l'immobilier.
Bien que l'offre de logements se soit amÃ©liorÃ©e, les logements d'entrÃ©e de gamme restent rares dans la plupart des rÃ©gions du pays, ce qui maintient les prix des logements Ã  un niveau inabordable pour les primo-accÃ©dants et nuit aux ventes d'entreprises telles que Weyerhaeuser. Les ventes nettes de son unitÃ© de produits du bois, la plus importante en termes de revenus, ont baissÃ© de 19,6 % pour atteindre 1,24 milliard de dollars, Ã©galement affectÃ©es par des coÃ»ts de fabrication plus Ã©levÃ©s.
Au quatriÃ¨me trimestre, la sociÃ©tÃ© prÃ©voit une augmentation sÃ©quentielle du bÃ©nÃ©fice de base pour le segment des produits du bois. Les ventes du segment Timberlands ont Ã©galement baissÃ© de 5,4 % pour atteindre 493 millions de dollars au troisiÃ¨me trimestre, pÃ©nalisÃ©es par des rÃ©coltes plus faibles dues aux risques d'incendies de forÃªt dans ses actifs du nord et au temps pluvieux dans le sud. La sociÃ©tÃ© a dÃ©clarÃ© un bÃ©nÃ©fice net de 28 millions de dollars, soit 4 cents par action, pour le trimestre clos le 30 septembre, contre 239 millions de dollars, soit 33 cents par action, l'annÃ©e derniÃ¨re.

author: agencia
title: Activado hasta las 9.00 horas el aviso rojo por lluvias en Huelva
text:
MADRID, 1 (EUROPA PRESS)
La Agencia Estatal de MeteorologÃ­a (AEMET) ha activado el aviso rojo por lluvias en el Litoral onubense y en las comarcas de ArÃ©valo y el Condado hasta las 9.00 horas, por lo que Emergencias 112 AndalucÃ­a ha pedido extremar la precauciÃ³n en Huelva y evitar realizar viajes.
"Extrema precauciÃ³n con la DANA en Huelva. Aviso rojo por observaciÃ³n de lluvias en el Litoral onubense, AndÃ©valo y Condado hasta 9.00 ohras. ProtÃ©gete. Evita viajar", ha indicado el servicio de emergencias a travÃ©s de su perfil en la red social X.
Asimismo, ha informado de que hay mÃ¡s de 40 avisos por anegaciones en Huelva, Aljaraque, Cartaya, Punta UmbrÃ­a y GibraleÃ³n. En la Ãºltima hora se han acumulado 70 milÃ­metros de agua y se espera que en doce horas duplique la cantidad hasta llegar a los 140 milÃ­metros, segÃºn AEMET.
Por su parte, la comarca de Aracena se encuentra en aviso amarillo, al registrar una precipitaciÃ³n acumulada de 20 milÃ­metros de agua en la Ãºltima hora.
Las vÃ­ctimas mortales por el paso de la DANA han aumentado a 158 personas, la gran mayorÃ­a en la Comunidad Valenciana, dos en Castilla-La Mancha y una en MÃ¡laga. SegÃºn Ãºltimo balance de fallecidos por el paso de la DANA, en la provincia de Valencia hay 155 vÃ­ctimas mortales, ha informado el Centro de CoordinaciÃ³n de Emergencias de la Generalitat Valenciana.

author: Adrianna Freedman
title: â€˜GMAâ€™ Fans Rally Around Lara Spencer as She Reveals Alarming Health News
text:
It looks like Lara Spencer will be spending some time off her feet â€” literally.
The Good Morning America star is usually on the go when it comes to her busy work life. But ahead of the holiday season, Lara gave a surprise update about her health that left her followers stunned. She went [on Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/p/DDdVh04RfB-/) to share that she'd recently underwent two operations at the Hospital for Special Surgery, due to injuries she'd gotten on both of her feet. What's more, as she posted photos with surgeon Dr. Martin O'Malley and showing off her bandaged feet, she delved a bit into what prompted her to go for the procedures in the first place.
"If I look a little groggy it's thanks to this guy who just gave me a new pair of boots," she joked in the caption on December 11. "My right foot was easy â€” just had plate removed from surgery last year. The left is a bigger deal from a very old college diving injury. I was doing a reverse one and a half and hit the board, shattering toes and joints. Back then they said there was nothing you could do except tape it, let it heal, and live with the pain. Today there are much better options, thanks to surgeons like Dr. Marty O'Malley at HSS. These boots were made for walkin ... "
When Lara's followers learned what happened, they immediately rallied around to wish her the best in her recovery.
"Oh my @lara.spencer I hope you heal up fast and pain free â¤ï¸," one person wrote in the comments. "Ouchhhhh! Speedy recovery! ðŸ’•ðŸ’•ðŸ’•ðŸ’•ðŸ’•ðŸ’•," another replied. "Ouch Lara!! Feel better â¤ï¸ didnâ€™t know this about your feet ðŸ¦¶. ðŸ™ ðŸ™ for you," a different follower added.
Given how Lara can't necessarily be on her feet right now, folks shouldn't expect her to make an appearance on GMA any time soon. But when fellow co-anchor George Stephanopoulos called in on the air on December 13 to check in on her, she gave an update on how she's been feeling.
"Yes, just kicking back, you know, relaxing. The uzhe," she said on the air, per [People](https://people.com/good-morning-america-lara-spencer-double-foot-surgery-8760985). "Ah, yes, I feel fine. Thank you, George, for asking. All is well."
Lara [attended Penn State University](https://www.psu.edu/news/arts-and-entertainment/story/good-morning-penn-state-alumni-association-chapter-connects-lara) on an athletic scholarship for springboard and platform diving. She later graduated with a degree in broadcast journalism and was named an All American Athlete in her senior year.
We're sending Lara well wishes for a speedy recovery!
[Good Housekeeping US](https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/life/entertainment/a63202009/gma-2024-lara-spencer-foot-surgery-health-instagram/)
[Adrianna Freedman](/author/245093/adrianna-freedman/)
As the entertainment and news editorial assistant for Good Housekeeping, Adrianna (she/her) writes about everything TV, movies, music and pop culture. She graduated from Yeshiva University with a B.A. in journalism and a minor in business management. She covers shows like The Rookie, 9-1-1 and Grey's Anatomy, though when sheâ€™s not watching the latest show on Netflix, sheâ€™s taking martial arts or drinking way too much coffee.

author: NewIndianXpress
title: IISc develops clean, green cooling tech for Indian Navy
text: IISc develops clean, green cooling tech for Indian Navy The Navy wanted to be the first in India to introduce a green technology for cooling which is compact and best suited for its ships and submarines. Published: 06th January 2024 07:46 AM | Last Updated: 06th January 2024 07:46 AM | A+A A- BENGALURU: A team of seven scientists and researchers from Indian Institute of Science (IISc) has developed a clean green cooling technology using carbon dioxide (CO2). But this time, the technological innovation is for the Indian Navy. The team from the Interdisciplinary Centre for Energy Research (ICER), IISc, developed a transcritical CO2-based refrigeration and heat pump system. The system has completed 1,300 hours of testing at Maharashtra-based naval base INS Shivaji. It will be officially inaugurated by the Navy this month. Elaborating on the refrigeration system, the researchers at ICER, told The New Indian Express: â€œCurrent refrigeration systems use synthetic chemicals such as HFCs and HFOs for cooling. These synthetic refrigerants emit significant greenhouse gas emissions. The Navy wanted to be the first in India to introduce a green technology for cooling which is compact and best suited for its ships and submarines. It approached IISc for a unique room cooling system using CO2, which is reliable, robust and provides stable cooling, and at the same time can also be used for heating.â€ Tech to suit tropical conditions India does not develop synthetic refrigerants now. Such systems are developed by Western countries and either imported or manufactured in India under a license agreement. Presently, it is difficult to safely recycle synthetic refrigerants. Hence, they are either silently vented to the atmosphere or stored and burnt, only adding to pollution. Propane, Isobutane, CO2 and ammonia are natural refrigerants that can be used for cooling and for heating. However, they have not been aggressively promoted so far as they need a fair amount of research, training and investments. Also, with hydrocarbons being flammable, there are strict regulations on permissible charge limits. But CO2 is not only inflammable, it is also safe and non-toxic. Being a natural refrigerant, it is being aggressively promoted for heat pump applications in supermarkets in European and other countries in the West. Besides heating, CO2 can be used for cooling and deep freezing up to minus 50 degrees Celsius and also for power generation up to 1100 degrees Celsius. This transcritical CO2 system for cooling that has now been developed for the first time in India by IISc researchers and is installed at INS Shivaji has been re-engineered to suit the tropical environmental conditions. The work was executed by ICER faculty along with industry partners Triveni Turbines, Tata Consulting Engineers (TCE), Danfoss, Modelicon through the industrial research wing of IISc, the Foundation for Science, Innovation and Development (FSID). The system has a cooling capacity of 100 kW and supplies cooling water at seven degrees Celsius to an air-handling unit used for room cooling and for their food items. The system has a charge of 35kg of CO2 and has not been topped up or replaced since its commissioning in September 2022. Based on the successful trials, the Navy intends to scale up the system to 750 kW or more and deploy it on one of its vessels. â€œWe found that the system performed well and was on par with a synthetic refrigerantbased system. The advantage of CO2 for the Navy was a significant reduction in the footprint which is one-third the size of a similar capacity synthetic refrigerant-based unit. Additionally, the system was found to cool much faster and adapt better to changing ambient conditions compared to the existing systems,â€ the team said.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Letter: Neither Joe Biden nor Donald Trump look willing to tackle national debt
text: As we get closer to the November 2024 election, I cannot understand how any parent or grandparent could fill in the small box beside Joe Bidenâ€™s or Donald Trumpâ€™s names. Both presidents boast about the great economies and stock market values their leadership created. Neither mention the fact the illusion of great economies was and is created by printing and borrowing money and leaving the debt for our spending to our grandchildren for repayment. Our military that Americans are so proud of is being financed with our grandchildrenâ€™s credit card. The hundreds of thousands of migrants pouring in through our southern border are often being fed, housed, transported around the country and provided health care for, again with our grandchildrenâ€™s credit card. Instead of Congress raising taxes, the federal government sells bonds to cover their spending . We find ourselves in a position where apparently even China doesnâ€™t even want to buy our bonds . U.S. Sens. Susan Collins and Angus King can seemingly stand on the bully pulpit any time they wish but I have heard no concern for our grandchildrenâ€™s futures from either. Right now, the House and Senate are locked into debate on how much money should we supply to Israel, Ukraine and our southern border, with hardly a word about asking voters to ante up to pay for this American generosity. I often wonder if Americans had to sacrifice to pay for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, pay for Central and South Americans to move to the United States, pay for weapons being sent to Ukraine and Israel would we make that sacrifice. Of course, the answer is no, and I expect that Trump, Biden, King and Collins would join the ranks of the unemployed if they did ask voters to pay up to cover their spending. Unfortunately, as long as our grandchildren canâ€™t say anything about losing their futures our largesse will continue. Richard Ginn Bucksport

author: Corinne Westeman
title: Mines cross country teams ready to build on last yearâ€™s successes
text: [Denverâ€™s Washington Park](https://www.denver.org/listing/washington-park/6828/) will be the linchpin of the Colorado School of Mines cross country teamsâ€™ 2024 season. The Orediggers kick off [their fall running schedule](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/schedule) Sept. 21 at the annual Roadrunners Invitational. Coach Chris Siemers and two senior runners expected it to be a good way to â€œget the rust offâ€ after a long summer, and they hoped Mines fans would pack the sidelines. â€œThat first race is always special,â€ graduate student Logan Bocovich said. â€œJust to see individually where youâ€™re at and see how the teamâ€™s been putting in the work.â€ However, Siemers said the Orediggersâ€™ second meet there [in November](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/schedule) will be much more important. The NCAA Division II South Central Regional Championships will be [at Washington Park Nov. 9](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/schedule). Siemers said it gives his runners a noticeable advantage, as they wonâ€™t have to travel two weeks before the national meet. â€œAny time you travel, especially to another time zone, youâ€™re compromising your sleep,â€ Siemers continued. â€œThatâ€™s the most important thing for a college student-athlete, especially at Mines.â€ He hoped the Oredigger faithful would make the 16-mile trek to Washington Park and cheer on the Mines teams [Nov. 9](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/schedule) as they try to qualify for nationals. The NCAA Division II National Championship meet will be [Nov. 23](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/schedule) in Sacramento, and Siemers said the Orediggers did well the last time the teams competed there. He described the course as â€œhonest,â€ and was confident the Mines menâ€™s and womenâ€™s teams would build on [last yearâ€™s second- and third-place national finishes](https://coloradocommunitymedia.com/2023/11/20/runners-up-mines-xc-places-2nd-3rd-at-ncaa-championships/), respectively. â€œI think both teams set their bar high in terms of mileage and quality over the summer,â€ Siemers said. â€œThey were hungry, and they made sure to get the work in. Thatâ€™s going to allow us to reach our full potential this season.â€ While both teams lost four of their top seven runners from last year, Siemers believed the Mines menâ€™s team has the best one-two-three punch in the country in [returning runners](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/roster) Bocovich, Logan Scomparin and Paul Knight. On the womenâ€™s side, he said redshirt senior Jenna Ramsey-Rutledge will contend for an individual national title, and three or four others will likely earn All-American honors. Even though both sets of Orediggers lost very strong runners and leaders, Siemers and redshirt junior Grace Strongman said the underclassmen are eager to learn and hungry to build on Minesâ€™ legacy. Strongman said sheâ€™s been helping mentor [the younger runners](https://minesathletics.com/sports/cross-country/roster), and in doing so, sheâ€™s learned just as much as they have, adding, â€œIt makes me a better runner to have people around me who are trying to be better runners too.â€ Siemers was confident in Strongman and other Orediggers who are taking more responsibilities and leadership duties within the teams, saying theyâ€™re eager â€œto represent the school and show that weâ€™re going to be contenders once again.â€ He added: â€œ(They) know itâ€™s their turn to step up â€¦ and help the program stay strong.â€ Making the uphill battles easier Because this is his last year of eligibility, Bocovich said he plans to leave everything out on the course. The graduate transfer joined Mines last season and placed 16th at nationals. While it was a â€œfantastic result,â€ he hopes to do even better this season. He wasnâ€™t on the Mines menâ€™s team when it won the 2022 national championship, but wanted to help replicate that success this fall. â€œIâ€™ve been going all-out (training) this summer,â€ he said. â€œ â€¦ The competition is as good as itâ€™s ever been. So, weâ€™re focusing on what we can do to better ourselves every day.â€ To that end, the Mines teams have been making good use of [their new training course](https://coloradocommunitymedia.com/2023/06/12/mines-athletics-receives-65-million-donation-for-scholarships-facilities/) south of the Mines Park area, [adjacent to U.S. Highway 6](https://maps.app.goo.gl/B7fmb8Dn7pZoKzh87). The course has a 1K loop and a 2K loop, and Strongman said one is perfect â€œfor some faster repsâ€ while the other â€œhas a monster hill.â€ Although most of this yearâ€™s race courses are flat, Strongman said the training courseâ€™s hill is the perfect practice for Chicagoâ€™s Lewis Crossover Invitational, which â€œopens on a pretty big hill.â€ Overall, she and Siemers said, the new training course has made the Orediggers stronger. â€œI know weâ€™re all set up to have some break-out seasons,â€ Strongman said of her teammates. Both Strongman and Bocovich are graduating this spring with their respective degrees, although Strongman said sheâ€™ll return next year for her final season and work on a masterâ€™s degree. Bocovich, meanwhile, said he plans to continue running after graduation. The exercise helps with work-life balance, he described, adding that heâ€™d like to run competitively for a few more years. If he finds a job in the Denver area, as he hopes, he was confident heâ€™d find teammates â€” both old and new â€” to run with regularly. â€œIâ€™m excited for that journey,â€ Bocovich said.
